message: A momentous moment, and one that's been a long time coming. Bravo to our PM, to those who've resisted the Brexit Deniers and the anti-democrats, to the electorate of the UK. We're leaving the unelected, authoritarian EU, once and for all.

Long may she stay to start to fix all the problems that have been caused over the last 25 years.

"The minority voted for BREXIT" - the majority of those who voted did
"It's not fair on Europeans" - our government is elected for our interests not any others.
Some of you may feel that we should remain but we are where we are and it was a democratic vote. If this vote was some how overturned then well that would mean a civil war would be justified as the majority of those who voted on this particular issue of which the government did make clear, means to leave all European Union institutions. There is nothing wrong with caring about ones international neighbours as I do but our government has a duty to carry out the wishes on a specific referendum in the name of the British public.
You are quite right. For England and Wales. Not for N Ireland and Scotland.
David Cunningham but regardless of individual status we are the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland so the majority rules regardless of individual standing.

Thomas George  you are wrong on two counts in your first paragraph. In Britain ppl elect members of parliament and not parties. Parties are groups of MPs with common interests. Secondly she is the PM because officially she enjoys the support of the  majority of MPs in the House of Commons.

However, although TM did not have to lead the tory party at the general election it is a convention of British politics that the party in power abide by the electoral manifesto of their party. 

It is also the convention of British politics that something as big as Brexit is done with more thought and caution.

But don't worry today we are a day closer to the demise of the tory party!

People elect politicians so that they (politicians)can take serious decisions on their behalf; On a substantial issue such as the choice between stay in or leave the EU, I'm confused as to the capability of the layman to form well-informed judgement. I mean the pros and cons of the whole relationship. Yes, during the campaign, much had been said on both sides, but let's not forget politicians will tell people what they want to hear. I believe it was a political gimmick to get to power. The repercussions are yet to come to light. On the contrary, it might prove to be more benificial than expected. One thing for sure the political class doesnt know actually how it's going to turn out. But people have given them carte blanche; so, if it misfires ,they cant be held responsible. It's the people who will face the music at the end of the day, or, reap the benifits. Moot point is, how many voted from instinct, or, heart, or, head? Any matter as serious as this cant be left to the uninformed, less-informed judgements of majority of the public. I belong to 'public'.

People elect MP's to represent them in parliament.   It is as simple as that.

They are representatives.   They are not our management.

We have always been a sovereign people.

The likes of labour and Blair and brown and the EU have forgotten that at their own peril. 

We are sovereign once again.

Some of us did our own extensive research :) !  Politicians can't really be trusted to tell the truth you know.  And it seems that even the "experts" were a little off course with their judgements as to what would happen after the vote.

What's amazing is the patience and dignity of Brexit voters. For nine months the political elite raged against them, ridiculed them, demonised them; branded them racist, destructive, "low information"; dragged their democratic choice to the courts in the hope that some clever judge would declare it illegitimate; took to the streets to call them idiots and buffoons and unwitting slaves of demagoguery; held them responsible for economic downturn and a return of fascism; declared them unfit for serious public life, which is apparently best left to experts. And yet Brexit voters didn't go mad or riot or crumble. They stuck to their principles (an amazing 96% say they'd vote for Brexit again) and patiently waited for their political choice to be acted upon. They kept their faith in democracy. They behaved liked the free-willed, autonomous adults that democracy needs in order to work and thrive.

The future is safe in their hands. Happy Article 50 Day!
Well said sir 👏👏👏👏👏
